item.title: Afghanistan: 'The sooner we finish, the better,' says Joe Biden
item.description: The US president says US troops are on track to end evacuations by a 31 August deadline.

item.title: Covid infection protection waning in double jabbed
item.description: Experts say it is to be expected and boosters may be needed, at least for some people, ahead of winter.

item.title: Charlie Watts: Jagger and Richards pay tribute to Rolling Stones bandmate
item.description: The Rolling Stones' Mick Jagger and Keith Richards salute drummer Charlie Watts, who has died aged 80.

item.title: UK self-catering holiday prices soar in pandemic
item.description: Holidaymakers are paying an average of £300 more per week than before the pandemic, analysis suggests.

item.title: Afghanistan: The 'exhaustion' of following the conflict from the UK
item.description: Ayesha, who lives in Britain, explains the mental and physical toll of following news from home.

item.title: Climate change: Consumer 'confusion' threatens net zero homes plan
item.description: Plans to decarbonise homes are too complicated and confusing, say consumer and industry groups.

item.title: Consultation begins on beaver reintroductions
item.description: The UK government is seeking people's views on whether beavers should return to England's rivers.

item.title: Smoking surge in young during Covid lockdown
item.description: The number of 18 to 34-year-olds smoking increased by a quarter in England during the first lockdown.

item.title: Afghanistan: World Bank halts aid after Taliban takeover
item.description: The announcement comes after the International Monetary Fund halted aid to Afghanistan last week.

item.title: US court rules asylum seekers must stay in Mexico
item.description: Asylum seekers must stay in Mexico while their claims are processed, the US Supreme Court rules.

item.title: Minister's wife goes ahead with legal action over nursery 'discrimination'
item.description: A nursery denies claims it discriminated against Humza Yousaf's wife and two-year-old daughter.

item.title: Serial thief targets designer frames in opticians across Scotland
item.description: Frames worth tens of thousands of pounds have been taken across Scotland by what retailers claim is the same thief.

item.title: The Papers: 'Race' to leave Kabul and Charlie Watts' tributes
item.description: The final days of the UK evacuations from Afghanistan and the death of the Rolling Stones drummer are the focus for the front pages.

item.title: Charlie Watts: The subtle magnificence of the Rolling Stones' drummer
item.description: He wasn't flashy or prone to pyrotechnics, but Charlie Watts was the heartbeat of the Rolling Stones.

item.title: Could this solar farm be a climate change solution?
item.description: UN experts say rapid innovative solutions are needed to end our dependency on fossil fuels. Could this new project provide an answer?

item.title: Haiti earthquake: Mother mourns daughter killed during christening
item.description: Locals say 22 people died when a church collapsed during a mass christening.

item.title: CEO Secrets: 'Tear up the business plan'
item.description: CEO Secrets: Brooklyn Brewery boss Eric Ottaway says - be ready to ditch your business plan.

item.title: Club completes challenge to bag all 282 Munros in a single day
item.description: Members of Carnethy Hill Running Club reached the summits of all 282 mountains in a single day.

item.title: Paralympics begin with powerful opening ceremony
item.description: The Tokyo 2020 Paralympics are officially under way after a powerful opening ceremony.

item.title: Mar Menor: Tonnes of dead fish wash up on Spanish lagoon's shores
item.description: Ecologists say pollution is to blame, as officials consider declaring the Mar Menor a disaster area.

item.title: McDonald's runs out of milkshakes in England, Scotland and Wales
item.description: Supply issues at English, Welsh and Scottish outlets are due to the lorry driver shortage, the firm says.

item.title: Billy Connolly: Challenges of Parkinson's getting worse
item.description: The 78-year-old has retired from live performances and says that making TV programmes is getting more challenging.

item.title: From earrings to tiles – what you can do with plastic waste
item.description: How people around the world are recycling plastic waste themselves and turning it into cool stuff.

item.title: Love Island: 2.8m see Millie and Liam crowned 2021 winners
item.description: That's a drop from the last summer series in 2019, but an improvement on last year's winter debut.

item.title: Social care charges: Disabled and vulnerable adults hit by steep rises
item.description: Many are facing a significant rise in the money they have to pay towards the support they receive.

item.title: How the world's oldest hat shop made it through lockdown
item.description: Lock & Co was first established in 1676 and has sold hats to the likes of Nelson and Winston Churchill.

item.title: Charlie Watts obituary: Jazz man who became rock superstar
item.description: The drummer kept his feet firmly on the ground despite the success of the Rolling Stones.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: The lowdown on being disabled in Japan
item.description: From moon riders to job quotas, three residents give the lowdown on being disabled in Japan.

item.title: Levelling up: The seaside town debating what change is needed
item.description: As a report says levelling up plans must consider local views, people in Rhyl debate the changes needed.

item.title: Madagascar on the brink of climate change-induced famine
item.description: The country is on the brink of experiencing the world's first "climate change famine", the UN says.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Swimmer Ibrahim Al Hussein's remarkable journey from war-torn Syria
item.description: An act of heroism, a perilous journey, a life-changing injury helped by a generous stranger. This is Ibrahim Al Hussein's story.

item.title: From Rhondda to Greenham and the US Supreme Court
item.description: Forty years ago, three sisters began their protest against US nuclear missiles coming to the UK.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Shot in the head in Angola, left for dead, now a Wetherspoons star
item.description: Cesar Kimbirima fled Angola after being shot four times and spending five months in a coma.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: A 'different' Games but Paralympians still hope to shine
item.description: The opening ceremony of the Tokyo Paralympics takes place on Tuesday with the Japanese capital still facing Covid-19 challenges.

item.title: Migrant crossings: What happens to migrants who reach the UK?
item.description: The government wants to cut the number of migrants crossing the Channel.

item.title: Sent to Halifax: One town's asylum story
item.description: What life is like for asylum seekers in a Yorkshire town - and what locals think about accepting more.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Sarah Storey wins 15th Paralympic gold
item.description: Britain's Sarah Storey wins her 15th Paralympic title for Britain's first gold medal at the Tokyo Games.

item.title: Hat-trick for teenager Archer as Villa hammer Barrow in Carabao Cup
item.description: Teenager Cameron Archer scores a hat-trick as Aston Villa ease into the third round of the Carabao Cup by thrashing Barrow.

item.title: England provoked us in second Test - India captain Kohli
item.description: Captain Virat Kohli says his India side will "not take a backwards step" when they meet England in the third Test at Emerald Headingley on Wednesday.

item.title: Ten-man Everton edge past Huddersfield with Townsend's first goal
item.description: Andros Townsend's late winner gives 10-man Everton a narrow victory over Huddersfield in the Carabao Cup.

item.title: Sussex beat Yorkshire by five wickets to reach T20 Finals Day
item.description: Sussex beat Yorkshire by five wickets at the Emirates Riverside in the first T20 Blast quarter-final.

item.title: 'I learnt so much from Wimbledon' - Raducanu ready for physical challenge of US Open qualifying
item.description: British prospect Emma Raducanu says she "learnt so much" from her rollercoaster Wimbledon debut as she prepares to begin US Open qualifying on Wednesday.

item.title: Real bid for PSG's Mbappe - Wednesday's football gossip
item.description: Real Madrid make Mbappe bid, Ronaldo pushes for Manchester City move, Manchester United lead Haaland race, plus more.

item.title: Bilal Sarwary: 'In the city I loved, suddenly nowhere was safe'
item.description: Journalist Bilal Sarwary saw the Taliban toppled in 2001 and his country reborn. So how does he feel now?

item.title: Afghanistan: How much opium is produced and what's the Taliban's record?
item.description: The Taliban claims opium poppy cultivation was stopped when it last held power in Afghanistan.

item.title: Afghanistan evacuation: Bittersweet relief for interpreter now in UK
item.description: An ex-interpreter for the British Army is happy to have escaped Kabul but still worried for his family.

item.title: What is Sharia law? What does it mean for women in Afghanistan?
item.description: The Taliban say they will govern Afghanistan according to Sharia, or Islamic law

item.title: Afghanistan: Why can't the UK hold Kabul airport without the US?
item.description: The US and UK have different timetables for the effort to evacuate people from Afghanistan

item.title: A Kabul evacuee's tale: Dread, chaos and the Taliban
item.description: An Indian woman tells the BBC of the on-and-off trauma of getting out of Taliban-held Afghanistan.

item.title: How are women in Afghanistan reacting to Taliban takeover?
item.description: The BBC's Secunder Kermani speaks to women in Afghanistan about the Taliban takeover.

item.title: How Afghanistan rattled Asia and emboldened China
item.description: US VP Kamala Harris tries to reassure Asian allies, as many ask: can they still trust America?

item.title: Afghanistan crisis: 'Hey world, do you care what happens here?'
item.description: A young woman shares her fears a week after the Taliban takeover of Afghanistan.

item.title: Hours without food or water in Kabul airport 'hell'
item.description: An Afghan man who worked for the British army tells the BBC he and his family cannot get through the crowds.

item.title: Ros Atkins on... Trump's Taliban deal
item.description: A deep dive into the US-Taliban deal of 2020 and its role in the militant group's takeover of Afghanistan.

item.title: Afghanistan: Foreign troops extension 'a clear violation' - Taliban
item.description: A Taliban spokesman says Afghans with passports can leave on commercial flights "at any time".

item.title: Kabul arrivals in the UK: 'We are the lucky ones'
item.description: UK troops are evacuating British nationals and eligible Afghans. Here are some of their stories.

item.title: Afghanistan: People at Kabul airport flee Taliban with just a suitcase
item.description: Afghans waiting at Kabul airport tell the BBC of their pain at fleeing the country they love.

item.title: Afghanistan: Where will refugees go after Taliban takeover?
item.description: Thousands of people are scrambling to flee Afghanistan after the Taliban took control of the country.

item.title: Afghanistan: The BBC's Lyse Doucet reports from Kabul airport
item.description: The BBC's Lyse Doucet witnesses Afghan men, women and children fleeing the Taliban regime.

item.title: Afghanistan: Trapped Nottingham family reach Dubai
item.description: The family with two young children were helped to escape from Kabul by the children's head teacher.

item.title: C-17: The US military plane carrying Afghans to safety
item.description: A Boeing C-17 safely carried 823 Afghans from Kabul last week, a record number for that plane.

item.title: Afghanistan: The desperate scramble to escape
item.description: The BBC witnesses scenes of chaos and panic as thousands still crowd Kabul's airport.

item.title: Afghan crisis: Russia plans for new era with Taliban rule
item.description: While Western governments raced to get their people out, Russia appears unfazed by the takeover.

item.title: Family of American taken by Taliban beg for return
item.description: Mark Frerichs, 59, one of the last Americans kidnapped by the Taliban, is stuck in Afghanistan.

item.title: How Afghanistan's media is changing under Taliban rule
item.description: The Taliban are currently on a media offensive but does their rhetoric match what’s happening on the ground?

item.title: 'They will kill me': Desperate Afghans seek way out after Taliban takeover
item.description: Many Afghans are desperate to escape after the Taliban takeover. Some fear there is no way out.

item.title: Afghanistan: Tears and applause as UK appeal helps refugees
item.description: People in Chapel-en-le-Frith in the Peak District collected more than 1,000 bags of donations in 48 hours.

item.title: The treacherous road to Kabul's airport
item.description: As thousands try to flee Afghanistan, the main route to the capital's airport has become treacherous.

item.title: Facebook moves to protect Afghan users' accounts amid Taliban takeover
item.description: The tech giant says it wants to reassure people worried about being tracked down by the Taliban.

item.title: Tanni Grey-Thompson column: 'Tokyo can still be a step forward for Paralympics'
item.description: Baroness Tanni Grey-Thompson believes the Tokyo Paralympics can still take the movement to another level.

item.title: Suzanna Hext: Paralympic swimmer prepares for Tokyo 2020 having watched London 2012 from hospital
item.description: From watching London 2012 from her hospital bed to swimming for ParalympicsGB at Tokyo 2020 - Suzanna Hext's Paralympic journey.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: What you need to know about Paralympic classification
item.description: From KL1 to PT2 and F11 to SB6 - everything you need to know about classification at the Paralympic Games.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Sport-by-sport guide
item.description: Twenty-two sports will feature in the Tokyo Paralympics - find out more about them all here.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Eight Great Britain athletes to watch at Games
item.description: From the 'Weirwolf' to a potential swimming star, who are some of the Great Britain athletes hoping to shine at the Tokyo Paralympics?

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Ellie Simmonds and John Stubbs to carry GB flag
item.description: Swimmer Ellie Simmonds and archer John Stubbs will carry the GB flag at Tuesday's Tokyo Paralympics opening ceremony.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Eight global athletes to watch at Games
item.description: From the Blade Jumper to the dancing star and the Tik Tok influencer, meet some of the global athletes hoping to make an impact at the Tokyo Paralympics.

item.title: Michael Knighton: The man who could have bought Man Utd for £10m but walked away
item.description: In August 1989, Michael Knighton celebrated his Manchester United takeover deal at Old Trafford. But the plotting against him had just begun.

item.title: India's living dead: 'They stared at me like I was a ghost'
item.description: If you're dead you can't own land - so if someone obtains your death certificate you could lose everything.

item.title: Peter Karlsson: The painful verdict on Swedish ice hockey player's 1995 killing
item.description: Peter Karlsson was stabbed to death in the street. His killer said he was protecting himself - via the so-called 'gay panic' defence.

item.title: 'How I found out my dad was a best-selling sex writer'
item.description: Sara Faith Alterman was always close to her father. Then she learned he was concealing a secret.
